intro: Tulipa connivens var. obtusata, commonly known as the Persian tulip, is a species native to the high-altitude regions of Central Asia. It is characterized by its large, showy flowers that typically bloom in shades of red, orange, and yellow. The plant produces narrow, grass-like leaves and has a compact growth habit. It is a perennial bulbous plant that thrives in well-drained soil and full sun. Its botanical significance lies in its role as a parent species in the development of many modern tulip cultivars.
